content.description: Slopey sidepulls and technical feet create a route that requires exacting beta.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 2 bolt anchor over the lip with chains.
content.location: Directly across from the crooked tree! The left of two bolt lines.

content.description: There are some semi-highball easy warm up boulders with many variations in this spot.  There are also some anchors located on the top of this climbs if you want to set up a top rope
content.protection: Pad if you want, or set up a top rope on the anchors located on the top of the cliff
content.location: To the left of the bolted routes. This is first area where the cliff is low enough for bouldering.

content.description: Small fat unattractive looking boulder.  Start on the right side of the boulder traverse left onto small chossy looking holds and work your way to the top. Easily the worst problem in the area.
content.location: Right of the Warm Up Area

climbs.name: Thinking is the Best Way to Travel

content.description: Juggy bottom, at the top there is nice compression and stemming moves on tubes.
Start with a short V2 boulder problem to get to your first cam placement. Then jam another cam in the easy finger crack. There is a spruce tree conveniently at the end of the route for an anchor.
content.location: This is the last notable climb at the northern end of the wall.

content.description: Start in the seam and move straight up.

Start with your left hand in the dynamite rail and your right on a small crimp at about chest height, from there move up to a good right hand crimp.  Be VERY CAREFUL when topping out, the rock about is very chossy.  It's best to traverse to the right after gaining the initial lip on this problem.
Start low somewhere in the plethora of pockets and find the pockets that work for you to gain the top. Around the Corner from Meaty Beaty Big and Bouncy
content.protection: Pad and a Spotter the landing is a little awkward

content.description: This is a boulder with a good amount of holds it is great to warm up. One would call this the variation station..
content.location: Approach from Hoosier daddy: go left for a while directly before Golden Shower (V2+).

content.description:
Climb up a crack until about 10 feet from anchors. Last part is mostly flat and barren except a small crack with a few crimps along with some vertical drill holes/lines. Pull up through crack and crimps to jugs under the anchors. 

  If you walk to the right of the crag, you can hike up a small hill that puts you on top of the wall where you can set up a top-rope.
content.location: Follow the crag all the way to the end, this is the last big face and overlooks the highway. This is the middle route of the three bolted routes on this face.

content.description: Start low on the jug rail, traverse right for a few moves before going up to a couple of small crimps then make a desperate throw for the good horn jug.
content.location: 30 feet to the left of Ball Buster

content.description: Climb up the slab to sharp pockets. Stroll around the corner to the top.

Start matched on the good left facing side pull.  Move up on underclings and small crimps with bad feet. This problem stays left of the faint dynamite rail on the wall. A V4 variation has the same start then moves to the right side of the dynamite rail.

Climb up to the choss to the overhanging section, use the amazing jugs and side pulls to do whatever variation you want. This boulder offers many opportunities to put up very hard problems. This one route deserves multiple pads, a spotter, and is a definite no fall problem.
content.protection: Atleast 3 pads, a spotter, and a will to go HIGH
content.location: One of the tallest boulders in the area, about 20 feet left of The Dirty Bird.

content.description: Climb along the left side of the black colored highball boulder.
content.location: To the left of Pocket Pinball

content.description: This is a classic route at Unlikely, it has history and many strong people have crushed this fun problem. This has many variation starts, one being a very low start on a good jug, cranking up to some small crimps. Work your way up the wall using an amazing iron deposits.
content.protection: One pad with a good spotter
content.location: Directly left of My hero the ZERO.

content.description: Work up this technical arete to a big finish on a jug that is a huge hole.
content.location: Directly to the left of The Golden Shower

content.description: Start with your right hand around the arete and a left hand in the dynamite rail.  Work your way up rail to gain the lip.
content.location: To the left of the Warm Up Area

content.description: This is a rather beta intensive route with constant tracking. The arete is off for this problem. From the juggy undercling make your move to the two small crimps, choose wisely. From there make a slight angle left working your way up the wall then a strong finish.
content.protection: need one pad great landing area.
content.location: This route is to the right of the highball problem.

content.description: Follow the line up to a bolt, break right to a block on the corner. Frolic to the slab in the gully. Stem up to jugs and a fin with hand jams. Reach left for jugs on the lower horizontal.  Walk the dog to the left, up the ledges to the top and wish is was not over. The top section is worth climbing it.Easy, fun one for the kids if they start in the right side of the gully.
content.location: The route starts on the face to the right of planes, trains, and automobiles.

content.description:
Climb up a wide, chossy crack to the first bolt. The crack thins up to form some more climbable holds. Lean back on this crack and climb up and past the second bolt. It is a bit run out to the anchors, but if you go out to the right aerie it is much easier to finish. If not, there are small crimps to bring you up to a jug above the anchors. 

  The bolts are not exactly brand new, but my friend did slip on a loose rock while leading it and the bolt held fine. If you walk to the right of the crag, you can hike up a small hill that puts you on top of the wall where you can set up a top-rope if you don't feel comfortable leading it.
content.location: Follow the crag all the way to the end, this is the last big face and overlooks the highway. This is the last route (to the right) of the three bolted routes on this face.

content.description: This is the classic route of the area, the base was dug out by some strong climbers. This is a low starting route off some amazing pockets either use the chaosy feet below or a harder version heel hook around the lip and make some technical moves and cut feet. ENJOY
content.protection: two pads the landing is not flat so be cat like

content.description: Unlikely Wall was created when IN-37 was built leaving behind a limestone wall above the highway. There are both bolted routes and boulder problems to be found here.  Although the rock can be very chossy in spots there are good climbs to be found. Please be aware that there are some bolts that have been cut, usually the first bolt of the climb. A stick clip easily reaches the second bolt.
